results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This home movie is shot in New Guinea. It includes scenic views over the bay (possibly Mapang), traditional dress, dance and reenactments, and a gathering and BBQ at the Faith Mission in Lufa.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:36:00 scenic view over the bay in Port Moresby, car in shot has ‘Mapang Missionary Home’ written on side
00:04:34:00 gathering of people wearing traditional dress from various districts
00:06:25:00 celebrations begin with parachuters landing from above into middle of football field
00:07:14:00 in traditional dress, people gather, reenactment of fighting, and dancing
00:10:33:00 ‘Faith Mission Hairo’ sign in Lufa, a BBQ and gathering of people including Evelyn Sinclair
00:12:33:00 another gathering at S.I.L. (Summer Institute for Linguistics) in Ukarumpa

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Netherlands, Switzerland and Wales, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film depicts a trip to the Netherlands and Switzerland, beginning in Welshpool, Wales. It features scenes of “The Dingle” gardens, country fairs, folk dancing, show jumping in Welshpool, Dutch seaside, canal trips in the Netherlands, streetscapes, countryside, farm life, Rotterdam, Spannenburg, bus trip to the Alps, Switzerland, Brienz and Grindenwald.

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This home movie shows the filmmaker and his wife travelling around England in a small yellow mini. They begin in London and travel across England to Stonehenge, up through the south of Scotland up to Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park, back to Edinburgh and end up in Blackpool.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, we see a trip to Beechworth in 1969 for the ‘Gemboree’, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. The first ‘Gemboree’ was held in 1965 as a gathering of lapidaries to showcase gemstones and minerals and has continued annually since. The film opens with elaborate title cards setting up the film, which is credited to both Tibor and wife Merna Koller. The film contains footage of country Victoria and the festival, including great shots of cars, caravans and tents of the era. It also shows interesting footage of gemstones on display.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Combined Lapidary Clubs of Victoria presents’, ‘1969 Gemboree Beechworth’
00:00:27:00 ‘Script & Narration: John Royle’
00:00:59:00 ‘Compiled & Filmed by TZ & MM Koller’
00:01:05:00 a man exits a wooden shed in the bush
00:01:48:00 panning for gold in the river
00:02:31:00 signpost ‘Woolshed Falls’
00:03:05:00 children panning for gold
00:04:11:00 sausages cooking on a hot plate
00:04:30:00 ‘Welcome to Beechworth’ road sign, followed by views around the town
00:06:14:00 cars driving down the main street
00:06:24:00 a yellow banner stretched across the road reads ‘Dulux Paints Welcomes You to Gemboree ‘69, National Lapidary Festival’
00:07:44:00 handmade signs for various lapidary clubs and some great examples of caravans and cars of the era
00:09:14:00 crowds of people at the festival
00:12:21:00 1950s style cars
00:13:01:00 a large group of people in the bush prospecting
00:14:09:00 toddler in a play pen
00:14:56:00 a man grinding a gemstone on a grinding wheel
00:15:39:00 ‘Exhibition Entries This Way’ followed by prize winners of the Gemboree on display
00:18:32:00 gemstones on display in cabinets
00:20:18:00 a bonfire

description_for_label:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, we see a trip to Beechworth in 1969 for the ‘Gemboree’, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. The first ‘Gemboree’ was held in 1965 as a gathering of lapidaries to showcase gemstones and minerals and has continued annually since. The film opens with elaborate title cards setting up the film, which is credited to both Tibor and wife Merna Koller. The film contains footage of country Victoria and the festival, including great shots of cars, caravans and tents of the era. It also shows interesting footage of gemstones on display.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film contains family gatherings for birthdays and weddings as well as Christmas in 1979, a picnic in the Eastern Gardens in Geelong, a trip to Cairns and a tennis tournament in Launceston, Tasmania. There are several gatherings for family birthdays, one of which is Dorothy Nixon’s 50th celebrations.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows rural Victoria footage around Omeo. It features excavation of, and images of, the Kiewa Hydro Electric scheme including power station interiors and exteriors and dam footage. Also included are hobby farm images, of children and adults with calves and chickens and pet dogs and cats. There is footage of a man collecting cow manure from paddocks.

We see images of the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade with goats, horses, Ayrshire and Illawarra cattle, jinkers, floats, horse-drawn carts with advertising. There is also footage of children playing childhood games on the family farm – wheelbarrow races, chasey, ball games and piggy-backs.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan):

00:00:01:00 children feeding chickens on farm

00:00:59:00 two children with kitten fighting over who gets to hold it
00:01:15:00 children playing chasing, running games around trees in rural setting
00:01:26:00 children with grandmother playing with skipping rope in rural setting (good family images and fashion example)
00:01:35:00 family on ship with crew working in background

00:02:46:00 men and children playing piggy back, wheelbarrow races, ball games on rural property (ood footage of childhood games and playing)

00:05:17:00 Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade with Jinkers, horses and carts, floats and advertising carts
00:08:19:00 Carnation Milk factory interior and exterior
00:08:57:00 Mount Beauty postal address plaque

00:10:33:00 road sign with vintage car in background: road sign indicating Upper Kiewa Valley Road; Mt Beauty; Rocky Valley; Howmans Gap

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows Sydney street, harbour and beach scenes and a family holiday to Tasmania and New Zealand. There are scenes of Bondi Beach, Taronga Zoo and wild animals in captivity showing a monkey riding a bicycle and performing tricks with a trainer. There are scenes on board and farewelling a passenger liner and passenger steam ferries in Sydney Harbour.

There are street scenes around Hobart, including Wrest Point Hotel, and a road trip to Mount Wellington, showing views along the way. The film shows New Zealand port towns and ports as well as a tourist boat trip on the fjords and scenery at Milford Sound. The family visits Rotorua and a recreation of a Maori Village depicting traditional Maori dance and dress performed for tourists. There are also scenes on a cruise ship of recreational activities.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows family holidays and recreational activities including trips to the beach, road trips to regional Victoria, children’s playgrounds (including swings and slippery slides) farm animals, pets and women’s tennis.

There is footage of Melbourne during the 1956 Olympics, showing athletes warming up, relay track events, Flinders Street and St Paul’s Cathedral with Olympic decorations.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:00:57:00 bird’s eye view of 1940s cars on country dirt road
00:01:13:00 stationary 1940s car on dirt road, with passenger looking out window and driver posing in front of the car
00:01:18:00 wooden fire tower
00:02:09:00 children and mother walking down stone steps of picnic ground. Good fashion shots.

00:03:51:00 children in birthday party clothes
00:04:09:00 children on slippery slide
00:05:00:00 group of children posing and waving to camera (good children’s fashion shots)
00:06:07:00 farm animals and pets
00:06:42:00 1950s parked cars
00:07:40:00 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games Village showing flags and Olympic rings sign
00:07:54:00 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games athletics track and field event, relay event, including athletes from the Philippines and USA
00:08:12:00 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games street scene with Olympic rings, trams and cars on Flinders Street easterly direction
00:08:21:00 St Paul’s Cathedral with Olympic Games street decorations
00: 08:27:00 1950s Coles shopfront with John Batman quote
00:08:32:00 family members: grandfather and two children (good fashion examples)
00:08:52:00 family pet shots. Patting wire-haired fox terrier, cockatoo.
00:09:19:00 c1940/1950 Women’s doubles tennis match

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows snippets of family life while at play, at birthday celebrations and on holiday. We see the family drive across the bridge to Phillip Island and enjoy swimming and canoeing at the beach there. The reel also includes scenes of caravan camping, koalas and a trip to the war memorial at Mount Macedon. The family enjoy games of tennis, ball games and swings and roundabouts at a playground. The film includes good examples of fashion, Austin cars and recreational activities of the time.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:01:37:00 children with their dad in the water at the beach (good example of bathing fashion)
00:02:58:00 tennis match between mum and dad
00:04:29:00 car with caravan and family in bush camp setting
00:05:14:00 Austin car with family standing at the front talking and combing hair
00:05:58:00 children being pushed on swings in a park by their mother (good fashion and sunglasses references)
00:7:30:00 close-up of little girl’s face as she blows out her birthday candles and looks to camera
00:07:41:00 family in front of war memorial at Mount Macedon
00:08:36:00 steam train travelling on a country rail line
00:08:46:00 family looking out from a ferry window
00:08:52:00 kids on a roundabout at a playground
00:09:00:00 grandmother, mother and children sitting on a playground wall – the grandmother is shooting a water pistol.
00:09:08:00 children on playground roundabout and dad jumps on to join them
00:09:32:00 a koala sitting in a tree climbs to the top and looks down
00:09:45:00 family and friends stand in front of a picket fence (good example of family groups and fashion from the time)
00:10:01:00 wide shot as cars travel across the bridge to Phillip Island

00:10:14:00 POV from inside car as it drives over the Phillip Island bridge
